To the Sectional Committee for Physiology 
Paper by A.M. Turing, F.R.S.
On The chemical basis of morphogenesis 
Comments 
This paper is well worth printing, because it will convey to the biologist the possibilities 
of mathematical morphology more definitely than has often been done hitherto. The only 
danger is that he may be taken too literally as implying what <u>will <\u> happen and not 
what <u>May<\u> happen, though the text should make the point clear.
The mathematics are not very deep, and the mathematician will not get any 
new principles from it, though for him the detailed results may be handy, as not 
being perceptible without going beyond general principles into special cases.
I recommend acceptance - I should say for Phil Trans B, with the 
following minor points amended.
(1)(p16-17) I do not think I have understood what he is after. Is he trying 
to explain bilateral symmetry or its absence?
To the three alternatives 
at the foot of p16. I should say he ought to add another - the effect 
of <u>noise <\u> which is not rigorously symmetrical, even though it may be 
statistically so.
Here arises a question of grammar. I protest against sentences like 
“The laws are mirror image symmetrical “, as having two nouns 
qualifying an adjective. I would say he should explain what he is talking 
about and then, <s>with explanation <\s> having so defined it, use the term “bilaterally symmetrical “.
Alternatively it would be just tolerable to say “The laws are mirror-symmetrical “.
Either conveys the essential idea.
(2) p.44. I cannot follow the process at all, or where he is going to get his 
fig 2 from. I can quite see that it would happen this sort of way, but 
without the initial data being stated, the dappling might just as well be got 
by shaking out a wet brush over the paper. So this should be simplified.
(3) p59. I doubt the appropriateness of giving this paragraph at all. It is 
introducing a heavy new machinery, that is entirely appropriate for the 
spherical body, and no doubt will be used for that in later work. Here he 
only uses it to go to the first harmonic (written wrongly in the text, but no matter)
and thus explains gastrulation. But the machinery is far too heavy for such 
a simple purpose. It is only necessary to think of pumping the air out of a tennis 
ball to see it is bound to happen that sort of way.
C G Darwin
